title: harry meghan never happy royal
story: NewsopinionHarry and Meghan will never be happy in the Royal mafia - but can they ever really leave The Family Where  have we seen a powerful family put survival ahead of personal happiness, asks il Volpe di Fleet StreetShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  JAN Newsopinion" to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - Royal FamilySubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailItaposs been bugging me for ages, but Iaposve finally realised who Meghan Markle reminds me of.Itaposs Diane Keaton in The Godfather - the pretty ingenue who watches the man she loves be consumed by the all-powerful family business he always hated.The Royals have an awful lot in common with the Corleones. Both families enjoy immense wealth, but are forced to live in private compounds to avoid scrutiny.Their families and friends become their bodyguards, keeping their secrets and taking to the mattresses with them in times of trouble.The head of the family demands you swear an oath of loyalty, and everyone is kept in line by the consigliere or top courtier. Every son establishes their own court of supporters, who engage in power struggles with their siblings and parents.And legal issues can be an unwelcome intrusion, even on the day of a daughteraposs wedding. And there are rules that must be followed. You can do pretty much anything, run a casino badly, go bankrupt, get your toes sucked, have affairs. The worst crime is to go against the family, and the greatest punishment is exile. Perhaps Harry promised Meghan that within  years theyaposd have reformed the Royals to the extent they could be legitimate philanthropists. But in this family there are rigid lines of inheritance, and the next leader is always chosen in strict uterine order . As sixth in line to the throne, Harry is on course to become ever less-powerful in the family business. They wonapost be able to reform anything. But he, Meghan and Archie will, nevertheless, still have to follow all the rules.  When Harry married Meghan she, like Keatonaposs character Kay Adams, probably thought things would be dferent. That together they could reform an old-fashioned institution, and do something good with all that wealth and power.And theyaposve done their best. The Invictus games, the Grenfell tower cookbook, Harryaposs landmine campaign, Meghanaposs Smart Works clothing line helping poorer women into work, and her inspiration to others as a woman of colour.Heck, I was delighted just by her decision to walk down the aisle alone. Marriages are not about property being exchanged between men, but adults making a choice to walk alongside each other. If more people realised that, thereaposd be much less heartache in the world. No doubt Meghan and Harry wanted to continue his motheraposs work as a high-profile charitable campaigner. But they forgot one thing - she only ever came into her own when she left.  Once youaposre in The Firm, your friends have a path to wealth and fame by association, as well as hate and abuse. You have immense pressure, media attention, and political responsibilities.It becomes a matter of crucial national importance as to whether you are wearing a hat, and what this means for the monarchy. People discuss, at , what jewellery one of the outlaws wears to an event you both attend. Every word you speak, glance you throw, or pair of socks you put on has more ramications than an opening gambit in D chess.Youaposre not a person, when youaposre Royal. Youaposre a role. And Harry doesnapost have much of one any more.  So the best this well-intentioned, angst-ridden, slightly-uptight couple can do is to become like George and Amal Clooney - immensely wealthy and intensely secluded, with occasional forays into the public eye to do good or promote a cause, while raising their family in private. Theyaposd still be in a gilded cage, but itaposs one where - George and Amal may assure them - fewer rocks will be thrown at them.And perhaps Harry imagines that this way, they can remain friends with the family. There is no betrayal, no squealing to the feds, no abdication and subsequent exile. You can still go home for birthdays.But it takes only one ill-advised deal with a casino boss, plastic surgeon or drug gang kingpin and trouble would kick off again. Because, like the Corleones, you can never really leave this family.For all of us, it is ma fia - the nationaposs family. We watch their squabbles and compare them with our own. For centuries their character has had an impact on our history, and as long as Royals exist that obsession will not be easily dropped.Harry and Meghan could renounce everthing, and retire to a hut in Snowdonia, and thereaposd still be people with cameraphones. As millionaire philanthropists, they still wonapost be the Clooneys - every utterance will be interpreted through the lens of protocol and family politics. Meghan could neverto acting, because sheaposll never be able to convince an audience sheaposs anything but a princess.No matter how peripheral they become, there is still a potential for international diplomatic incidents. Just ask Uncle Andrew for details.Of course, itaposs unlikely the Queen would allow a polo pony to be slaughtered just to make a point, but itaposs still possible for a former Royal to wind up sleeping with the fishes.If Princess Diana had retained Royal levels of security after her orce, she would never have died in that underpass. The promise of protection, and the threat of removing it, is exactly how the mafia has always operated. For Harry and Meghan itaposs not a choice of which country to live in, or what rich friends to hang out with. They have to pick their poison.The th in line to the throne can become low-profile, stay wealthy, and become ever-less scrutinised the further they move down the line of succession with every subsequent birth. But that takes time, and patience. Radical change has never worked for the monarchy or the mob. Both focus on long-term survival. Harry and Meghanaposs instinct may well be to get out, in the interests of quick and immediate happiness. But as Michael Corleone discovered,you want to change the family you need to stay in it. Andyou stay in it, the family changes you. Itaposs best not to join in the first place.

Britain is preparing to evacuate thousands of UK citizens from the Middle East as experts fear the threat of war is far from over as Iran is expected to direct its proxy militias in the region to carry out more bloodshed. More than , Brits will fly home from Lebanon alone as Iran has a large contingent of Hezbollah supporters there. The Foreign Office advised against all but essential travel to the country. Embassies throughout the world remain on high-alert against attacks and are protected by increased security. Not only are local forces loyal to Iran a threat, but there are armed groups with links to Iran throughout the whole of Asia and that are also a threat in South America and Africa. The proxies could be anything from State supporters like the Shia sect Assad regime in Syria to Shia militia groups throughout Iraq and Syria, who are heavily-armed and supported by Iran. There are also Lebanese Hezbollah groups, funded by Iran as well as the Popular Mobilisation Units, which comprise of more than  mostly Shia militia groups. A senior British security source told the Mirror: “The whole region remains a powder keg. Lebanon is very tense and could quickly erupt as Iran urges its proxies to take action, militants are generating hatred across the country.  “We have a team ready to fly out and scope out how we would extract people. “The priority is to locate available ships or ferries that we can hire and get into Lebanon and transit people to Cyprus.” A similar operation was carried out in  during a war between Hezbollah and Israel. However, influential Iraqi Shi’ite cleric Muqtada al-Sadr yesterday called on militia groups not to carry out attacks. He said: “I call on the Iraqi factions to be deliberate, patient, and not to start military actions, and to shut down the extremist voices of some rogue elements until all political, methods have been exhausted.”US President Donald Trump yesterday boasted that “Iran appeared to be standing down” .He revealed that no Americans were killed or injured as Tehran fired ballistic missiles at two bases in Iraq.  Most were aimed at the al-Assad base, some  miles west of Baghdad and two hitting a target in Erbil, north Iraq. Two rockets fell inside Baghdad’s heavily fortied Green Zone, which houses government buildings and foreign missions, but caused no casualties. The attacks were in response to the killing of the Iranian’s top General Qasem Suleimani by the US last week. Iran’s Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei said the missile attacks were a “slap on the face” of the US and demanded US troops leave Iraq. In an address at The White House, Mr Trump said: “As long as I’m President Iran will never be allowed to have a nuclear weapon. story: NewsUber driver cleared of palace sword attack caught in tourist hot spot terror plotMohiussunnath Chowdhury, of Luton, Bedfordshire, appeared in Woolwich Crown Court accused of terrorism related offences targeting famous London landmarks including Madame TussaudsShareByHelen William:,  JAN NewsMohiussunnath Chowdhury at the Old Bailey in June  " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - Royal FamilySubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man told uncover police officers of his plans to launch a deadly terror plot just two years after being cleared of a sword attack on police outside Buckingham Palace, a court has heard. Mohiussunnath Chowdhury, , was motivated by dreams of martyrdom for the cause of Islam, and inspired by preachers of hate like former al-Qaeda spokesman Anwar Al-Awlaki, prosecutor Duncan Atkinson QC said. The lawyer told a jury at Londonaposs Woolwich Crown Court that Chowdhury had been found not guilty at the Old Bailey of a terror charge after attacking police officers with a sword outside Buckingham Palace in August . In that incident, two unarmed officers suffered cuts to their hands when they fought to disarm him near the Queenaposs London residence as Chowdhury shouted repeatedly Allahu Akbar .  After he was cleared at the Old Bailey, Chowdhury was driven by dreams of martyrdom, the court heard. By  he was planning to kill members of the public at busy tourist hotspots such as Londonaposs Madame Tussauds and the Gay Pride parade, according to Mr Atkinson. But Chowdhury was unwittingly confiding his plans to undercover police officers who had him under surveillance, the court heard. Mr Atkinson said: Believing them to be as sincerely committed as he was, he told them of his devotion to the cause of violent Islamic extremism, the basis for this devotion and the skewed religious beliefs that underpinned it. Mr Atkinson added: Various potential targets were discussed between the defendant and those he believed to be committed to the same cause and the same forms of violence as himself. The targets mentioned included Madame Tussauds in London, the Gay Pride parade and an attack on tourists on a London open-top tour bus. The object was to unleash death and suffering on non-Muslim members of the public who happened to be present, using a firearm, sword and even a van as part of an attack. Mr Atkinson said Chowdhury even bragged he had deceived the jury which cleared him at his previous trial. The prosecutor told jurors they could consider Chowdhuryaposs assertions to the undercover officers that he was indeed trying to carry out a terrorist attack in  and that he had deceived the earlier jury that acquitted him of it. Mr Atkinson added: Whatever the position in , he was unquestionably preparing for terrorism in . Mr Atkinson said Chowdhuryaposs sister Sneha Chowdhury, , had better reason than anyone to understand what her brother was thinking and wanting to achieve, but she did nothing to stop him.  After being cleared in December , Chowdhury posted an Instagram message in which the police officer who had confronted and disarmed him outside Buckingham Palace was described as a cuck. From January , three undercover officers were working to earn Chowdhuryaposs trust and to tap into his extremist views, the court heard. Chowdhury was able to buy a replica Glock gun and told them what he was planning to do and why.  Mr Atkinson said: He told them of his training regime, and sought to involve them in his firearms-related training. He told them of what he was wanting and planning to do, and sought to involve them in the carrying out of one or more terrorist attacks. Chowdhury had claimed the incident outside Buckingham Palace had been an attempt at suicide and it was not an attack. In the lead-up to this incident he had made references on WhatsApp to the Westminster jihad attackerapos Khalid Masood, who had killed six people. He noted that Masood had been shot by police and said that he stood up to the bastards.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailConsumer watchdogs are demanding that Whirlpool refunds customers left out of pocket in the chaotic recall of fire-risk washing machines. A week before Christmas, the firm announced , Hotpoint and Indesit machines had faulty door locks that could lead them to overheat and catch fire. Whirlpool, which recalled tumble dryers over fire fears earlier last year, advised people with affected washing machine models to stop using them. As their recall finally gets under way tomorrow, Which  is calling for Whirlpool to reimburse people who felt they had no option but to pay for replacement machines. And it voiced “serious concerns” that people will be left with potentially dangerous machines for months as they wait for an engineer to fix or replace them. Which  called on Whirlpool “to do the right thing” and offer refunds, but the company tonight refused to bow to pressure and said engineer appointments would begin on Monday. It said repair or replacement was “the most effective means of removing this risk” and said it was following “industry best-practice procedures” for the UK. It added: “Whirlpool has been able to reassure % of [customers] they do not have an affected appliance and can continue to use their products safely as normal.”  More than  MPs have written to Whirlpool about fears over the recall. Labour MP Rachel Reeves said: “If they cannot swtly fix or replace machines with potential problems, they should offer affected customers a full refund.” Whirlpool customers told Which  how they had to dig into savings to buy new machines or do their laundry at friends’ and relatives’ homes, or launderettes. By Sue Davies - Which  Head of Consumer Production Whirlpool will finally launch its recall of more than half a million fire-risk washing machines tomorrow. The move will bring some relief to hundreds of thousands of customers who have already faced weeks of inconvenience and racking up huge bills at the launderette. But the bad news is that the company’s offer of a repair or replacement machine - but no refund - could leave many facing months of waiting, without any way to wash their clothes. This approach is all too typical for the American appliance giant - a company that has earned a reputation for shoddy products and even shoddier treatment of its British customers. Whirlpool broke the news of a potentially lethal door switch fault days before Christmas - the worst possible time for families preparing to host friends and relatives. Alarmingly, the consumers put at risk by this defect were told nearly two months after Whirlpool first warned its wealthy investors in the US about a possible safety issue with some washing machines, which they were assessing. Over the festive break, Which  was fielding concerns from customers struggling to get by without a washing machine or seeking reliable information about the recall. In some cases these customers had found it dficult to establishtheir Hotpoint or Indesit washer was one of those affected after a  start on Whirlpool’s first attempt to warn consumers of this threat to their safety - with a website that crashed on day one. Others found it impossible to get through to a phone helpline, even after trying to call dozens of times. Many people were confused by conflicting information about whether or not it was safe to use their machine. Whirlpool said yes - but only at C. The government’s Office for Product Safety and Standards seemed to say no - unplug your machine. Who to believe  Joanne Braithwaite, from Stanford-le-Hope in Essex, told us she had no alternative but to keep using her machine at a lower setting and said that is just not practical for a family of four - and to make matters worse, her Whirlpool tumble dryer has since packed in as well. Those who have understandably chosen to take no risks and turned their machines off are having a miserable time too. Some families are taking matters into their own hands and forking out for a new washing machine themselves - not an option available to everyone, of course. Many have echoed the view of Fiona Thompson, , who branded Whirlpool “an absolute disgrace” and said she would never have one of the company’s products in her home again. Following on from the tumble dryer fire scandal which resulted in another recall last year, the reality is that many British consumers have lost faith in what they see as a tainted brand. Whirlpool needs to do the right thing and offer refunds to these people - and to those who simply can not afford to wait for many weeks or months for a repair or replacement. The company says it is aiming to deal with registered machines in a matter of weeks. But with tumble dryers, we found a quarter of customers were being told they would have to wait more than six months for a repair.That can’t be repeated with an essential appliance like a washing machine. People need the money to put towards a new machine now. MPs including Labour’s Rachel Reeves - who chaired Parliament’s influential Business Committee when it produced a damning report last year into Whirlpool’s handling of the ongoing tumble dryer saga - have also called for refunds or compensation for customers. The one consolation for the majority of those affected is that they have been spared the horror of a house fire caused by a faulty appliance. Not everyone has been so lucky. Whirlpool says  fires have been linked to this fault, which causes a machine’s door-locking mechanism to overheat - the latest in a series of safety scandals. Previously, a coroner blamed an electrical fault with the door switch of a Hotpoint tumble dryer for a  fire in north Wales that killed two men - Bernard Hender, , and Doug McTavish, . Meanwhile, the fire-risk heating element fault affecting . million tumble dryers has been linked to more than  fires and Whirlpool only agreed to launch a full recall after years of pressure from organisations like Which  and newspapers like The Mirror.The company was shamed in Parliament for using “chilling” tactics including gagging orders that prevented fire victims from speaking out about the danger. Shockingly, all this means that right now there may well be more than a million potentially lethal Whirlpool products in people’s homes. Something stinks about this situation - and it’s not just the piles of festering laundry lying around the homes of thousands of frustrated washing machine owners. The product safety system in this country is rotten to the core - failing time and again to put public safety ahead of business interests. This latest safety scare should be a wake-up call that brings about a much needed overhaul of consumer protections in this country. There must be a full, transparent investigation into this latest washing machine fault - including what Whirlpool knew and when - to establish what is going wrong with the system. And, as a first step to restoring public confidence, the government’s failing Office for Product Safety and Standards must be replaced. British consumers deserve a truly independent regulator with real powers to stand up to the might of global corporations and ensure dangerous products are kept out of people’s homes.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA Christian woman who waited until her wedding night to lose her virginity was horried to find she still was unable to have sex. Stephanie Muller, , wants to raise awareness of a medical condition that left her unable to consummate her marriage for two years. Stephanie and -year-old new husband Andrew decided they would wait to have sex until they wed after meeting at their local church in New York in . The couple became an item in  and courted for two years before tying the knot in May . However, on their honeymoon, attempts to have sex where thwarted when they found penetration too dficult. Stephanie ended up with a severe yeast infection which medication failed to clear up over a three-month period. During that time she found having a pelvic exam so painful that she ended up in tears and shaken. Once the infection cleared up they tried again to no avail and she said the couple ended up feeling like roommates. They eventually discovered what was at the root of the problem in January  when Stephanie was diagnosed with vaginismus by her gynaecologist. The condition results in Stephanieaposs vagina tightening up when the couple attempt to have intercourse. Stephanie said: Saving sex for my wedding night was my personal choice. I wanted to save sex for my wedding night because I didn’t want to have sex with anyone that wasn’t my husband.  I personally believe that sex is a very intimate and special thing, and I didn’t want to share that with someone  that I would not end up marrying. Stephanie said she felt ashamed that she wasn’t able to have sex with her husband and it made her feel like they were friends. My husband and I have talked about how vaginismus really de-sexualised our relationship it was almost like living with a roommate, she said. We would even be careful about other physical things because neither of us wanted to suggest trying to have sex, be disappointed, and the night ending in tears.Stephanie was referred to the Vaginismus and Women’s Therapy Centre but this would not be covered by her health insurance. So instead she was prescribed her with Vicodin, a medicine used to relieve moderate to severe pain, to have sex with her husband. In September  Stephanie looked at other things she could do and the couple decided not to let her condition affect their intimacy.  In January last year the couple undertook a five-month treatment course at Womenaposs Therapy Centre in Plainview, New York, that the break through happened and Stephanie is now healed. She said: Having vaginismus is a heavyweight, and what largely makes it so dficult is the isolation and shame that comes with it. My husband has been incredibly supportive throughout my journey with vaginismus.

story: NewsIran refuses to hand over black box from crashed passenger jet that killed The two flight recorders could reveal why the airliner came down in flames so soon after Iran’s ballistic missile strike against US troopsShareCommentsByChris HughesDefence and Security Editor:,  JAN NewsDebris of a plane belonging to Ukraine International Airlines, that crashed after taking off from Irans Imam Khomeini airport " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIran has refused to release the black boxes from a passenger jet that crashed shortly after take off killing , including three Brits. The two flight recorders could reveal why the airliner came down in flames so soon after Iran’s ballistic missile strike against US troops. Mystery has surrounded the disaster as the Boeing  was seen in unveried video burning while in mid-air after taking off from Iran’s main Imam Khomeini airport. There were  passengers and nine crew members on the Ukraine International Airlines flight PS to Kiev when it crashed. The plane’s black boxes have been recovered, but the head of civil aviation in Tehran, Ali Abedzadeh, refused to hand them over to Boeing. The Ukrainian embassy in Iran initially issued a statement saying: “According to preliminary data, the plane crashed due to engine failure for technical reasons. As of now, versions of terrorist attack or missile attack are ruled out.” However, that claim was later deleted from the embassy’s website. Any previous comments about the cause were “not official”, the embassy said. A video on state media appeared to show the plane already on fire as it fell from the night sky.  Askedthe airliner could have been downed by a missile, Ukraine’s Prime Minister Oleksiy Honcharuk cautioned against speculation. But David Learmount, of news site FlightGlobal, said: “Whatever it was, it was very dramatic and very sudden, because the crew were not able to make an emergency call. “They had plenty of height which would have given them the time to make a call. You try to work out what very dramatic thing can go wrong with an airliner...”

title: dee must bounce back and secure second spot says keeper hamilton
story: Dundee goalkeeper Jack Hamilton insists it is vitally important they quickly bounce back from defeat to Inverness and secure second spot in the Championship.The Dark Blues fell to fourth in the table after a - defeat to second-placed ICT at Dens on Saturday and now lag six points behind the Highlanders.Sitting in the final promotion play-off spot is far from where the Dee would have hoped to have been at this stage of the season.However, Hamilton admits they can only look at themselves to recty that and make their path to any potential push for Premiership promotion clear as early as possible.“You don’t want to be coming towards the end of the season wondering where you’ll finish. Ideally, we’ve got to be finishing second,” he said.“It takes out that extra two games in the play-offs and that’s where we want to be, that’s what we’re looking towards and realistically we’ve got the squad to do that.“We’ve got to look to win every game and it’s down to us really. Dundee United are sitting  points ahead so,they weren’t to win the league it’d be a disaster on their part.“We’ll just concentrate on ourselves. There’s no point looking at anybody , each week we don’t look at other results thinking ‘whatwe do this and that’ we just focus on our own performances and how we’re going to beat teams.“We need to start getting three points on the board again.”Ending their four-match unbeaten run, particularly after a morale-boosting derby draw the weekend previous, with a loss against the Caley Jags stung for Dundee and Hamilton.And the -year-old is determined to put that right as soon as possible with three points when third-placed Ayr United come to town on Saturday.The former Hearts man added: “It was really disappointing off the back of a good run of games and it just wasn’t acceptable.“We started sloppy and it just continued throughout. title: dundee 0 2 inverness dismal dee drop to fourth with ict defeat
story: Dundee dropped to fourth in the Championship table as they fell to a - defeat to Inverness at Dens Park.First-half goals from Aaron Doran and James Keatings did the damage as John Robertson#s Caley Jags strengthened their grip on second spot.Ayr winning at Dunfermline meant the Dark Blues dropped to the fourth and final promotion play-off spot,  points behind leaders Dundee United.Dee boss James McPake stuck with the same line-up which earned a point in the Dundee derby with -year-old Fin Robertson starting in the middle of the park after a terric display at Tannadice.Inverness were the first to threaten but Nikolay Todorov could only head Miles Storey#s cross over the bar after three minutes.Caley skipper Carl Tremarco went closer on nine minutes as he got on the end of another Storey cross after a period of pressure. However, Dark Blues keeper Jack Hamilton gathered the header comfortably.Hamilton then made a smart stop from a whipped Keatings free-kick minutes later as the visitors continued to push for the opener.On  minutes Charlie Trafford forced a routine save out of Hamilton before, just a minute later, Inverness got the goal their play deserved.In acres of space down the right, full-back Shaun Rooney had the freedom of Dens Park to pick out Doran in the centre of the box and the Irish attacker duly lashed home from  yards.On  minutes, ICT were two to the good. From their own corner, Dundee compounded to lose possession and allowed the Highlanders to break.Former Dundee United man Keatings led the charge and finished the counter attack off himself, coolly slotting beyond a helpless Hamilton in the home goal.The Dark Blues huffed and puffed for the remainder of a dismal first half for them but were unable to lay a glove on Inverness as the boos rang out among the sizeable home support on the half-time whistle.Four minutes into the second period, Dundee forced Mark Ridgers into his first save of the afternoon as the ICT goalie stooped to turn Jordan Marshall#s long-range effort behind for a corner.Jordan McGhee was next to test Ridgers, firing in a dipping effort just before the hour mark, but the Caley stopper was able to gather.Moments later, Paul McGowan#s header from a deep Sean Mackie cross forced Ridgers to tip over as the Dee sought a way back into the contest.On  minutes, Kane Hemmings laid in Marshall but the left-back saw his effort from  yards deflected behind.Inverness# front four continued to look threatening but, largely, the Dee defence kept them quiet in the second .However, McPake#s men were unable to carve a way through an organised ICT defence with the rookie boss cutting a frustrated and under-pressure figure throughout.With Ayr and Dunfermline to face next, Dundee will certainly need to perform a lot betterthey are to stay in the mix for the promotion play-offs come the end of the season.Dundee XI : HamiltonKerr, Meekings , McGhee, Marshall Robertson, Dorrans, McGowan, MackieJohnson , Hemmings.Subs not used: Ferrie , Forster, Byrne, Moore and Cameron.Inverness XI : RidgersRooney, Donaldson, McHattie, TremarcoTrafford , Vincent StoreyKeatings Doran Todorov .Subs not used: Mackay , McCart, Curry and MacGregor.Referee: Don Robertson.Att: ,.

title: 80 years ago rationing was introduced in britain heres how the north east reacted in 1940
story: Branded as a “fair share for all” amid fears of nationwide food shortages, ration books were first issued  years ago today as part of measures in World War Two.The introduction of restrictions on January   was met with stoicism by Aberdonians, and city grocers told the Evening Express that so-called “Ration Monday” had “opened quietly” with arrangements working “satisfactorily”.As Britain cut down on imported food – and with supply vessels at the mercy of German submarines – the Ministry of Food brought in rationing to ensure everyone had access to basic foodstuffs.A report in the EE explained that “every man, woman and child in the country, from the Royal Family to their humblest subjects, has a ration book which ensures essential supplies”, with each person entitled to oz of sugar, oz of bacon and ham, and oz of butter a week.Sugar proved to be the most sought-after provision on the first day of the scheme.An Aberdeen grocer told the EE: “Sugar was the rationed foodstuff most asked for today.“Shop assistants found the customers quite cheerful about it all and there was a good deal of good-humoured banter about the care required so that none of the precious commodity should be spilled.”In the following days and weeks, recipes and suggestions of how to make rations go further were regularly printed in the newspaper, and there was widespread delight when it was announced on January  that bacon rations were to increase from oz to oz.The EE reported: “One leading shopkeeper said grocers had been worried.“They have had to take in sufficient supplies for their registered customers who have not been taking up all the supplies. There is plenty of bacon in Aberdeen # this will help grocers tremendously.”As war rumbled on, eventually most foods were covered by rationing with the exception of fruit and vegetables which citizens were encouraged to grow.The famous “Dig for Victory” campaign was spearheaded by Aberdeen man John Raeburn who was head of the agricultural branch at the Ministry of Food.Born in the city and educated at Mile End School before his family moved to Manchester, Prof Raeburn specialised in agricultural economics and joined the Government when war broke out.His branch was responsible for uniting a struggling nation in what was considered one of the most successful home front initiatives, inspiring millions to dig up lawns and public spaces.

title: end of an era as aecc arena be flattened
story: Work to knock down Aberdeen#s former exhibition centre is expected to begin in the coming weeks.Aberdeen City Council submitted a building warrant to demolish existing buildings at the Aberdeen Exhibition and Conference Centrein Bridge of Don, alongside agents Fairhurst.The site is no longer in use following the opening of the PJ Live arena in August last year.The multi-million-pound state-of-the-art event complex, which is in Bucksburn, now hosts all major events. vw, px"  The AECC first opened its doors in  and comprised of conference facilities and a multi-purpose arena.It has now been permanently closed.A building warrant was submitted in September to demolish buildings at the site including the main arena, which has now been approved by the local authority.Aberdeen City Council co-leader Douglas Lumsden said now the building warrant has been granted, the “intention” would be for that work to start “immediately”.He added: “That might include internal works first which people won’t be able to see.”As well as the removal of the old main arena building, the covered walkway that connects to the section of the conference centre next to the Holiday Inn Express will also be removed.It is expected that the value of the work to be undertaken will be around £,.The warrant has an expiry date of January   and all work must be completed by then.It is understood that the remaining conference centre will be retained as well as the nearby park-and-ride facility.Talks regarding the future use of the site are still ongoing.Plans were previously submitted to the local authority by developers Henry Boot in May  for the land, which hoped to create a mixed use development including approximately  residential units, properties for commercial and business use, a recycling centre and park-and-ride facility.The application is still pending and there was a number of documents uploaded on to the site in , along with a letter of objection received last year.It stated: “The site would have been better used as a new north-east HQ and training hub for Police Scotland with Queen Street being disposed of.“There would be ample space to create a specialist training facility, which Police Scotland does not have anywhere north of the central belt.”Discussions have also been under way with the King’s Community Church over the site, with the church keen to move from its base on King Street.The church began in  with a small gathering before it moved to the city centre church in  where it has remained.An Aberdeen City Council spokeswoman said: “A building warrant to demolish the arena at the old AECC and a covered walkway to the adjacent hotel has been approved by the planning authority.”

title: getting home would mean the world to me and my family says aberdeen cricketer solo nqweni
story: An Aberdeen cricket star struck down by a rare illness while in the north-east has admitted he felt like a prisoner in his own body – but is aiming to recover for the sake of his family.Solo Nqweni, , moved to the area last April to play for Aberdeenshire Cricket Club.In July he began feeling unwell and put it down to a virus.But days later he had been put in an induced coma after being diagnosed with Guillain Barre syndrome, a serious autoimmune disorder which affects the nervous system.It left Solo unable to walk, talk or even breathe unaided.Appeal to help Aberdeen cricketer fighting Guillain Barre syndrome fly home" src"https:www.eveningexpress fp news local appeal-help-aberdeen-cricketer-fighting-guillain-barre-syndrome-fly-home embed # secretArkeeed" data-secret"Arkeeed" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"Having spent three months in intensive care and a further three on the neurological ward at Aberdeen Royal Infirmary, Solo has now been given the all-clear to fly home with medical support.But the journey, which will require constant nursing provision, will cost around £,.And the star, who was a hit in his short time at Mannofield, revealed to The Evening Express how much he is missing his home.He said: “It would mean the world to me to go home. I have been in Aberdeen since April and I have been on my own away from family and my home. I’ve got a son, who is eight months old.“I came to Aberdeen to build my cricketing career and provide for my family.“Although I have had the support of my family being able to come to see me, it’s not the same as being at home, around my family and friends and being able to build that relationship with my son.“Going home to do my rehab and get strong to the point where I can walk again would mean the world to me and my family and friends.”Since he fell ill in July, Solo’s family have been making the arduous journey from South Africa to see him, operating in shts to ensure someone is always close at hand.And he admitted he would have struggled to get through the early days in intensive care without the support of them, his friends and his team-mates.Now, despite having many months of treatment left, Solo insisted he has high hopes for the future.He said: “It’s been dficult going from being in top shape and at the top of my game to, the next day, collapsing and not being able to use my body at all and not knowing what’s wrong with me.“The first three months in ICU were tremendously dficult and I felt like a prisoner in my own body in that I was paralysed from the neck down, not being able to move any of my limbs, not being able to eat, drink or talk and with numbers and beeps going on all around.“It was quite depressing at times but having my family to support me through it all made it a lot better and more bearable.“As I recovered day by day we slowly got used to the fact my situation was what it was and we couldn’t do anything other than be positive and mentally strong about the outcome.“My attitude changed and I started focusing on what I could do to get better in the situation I am currently in.”He added: “Once I moved to the neuro ward I started making progress physically. I started being able to eat and drink normally again, and after the tracheotomy was taken out, I was able to talk normally again. These things made a huge dference to my mood and my optimism and I started to feel normal again in a way.“The last three months in neuro have been quite positive and I have been getting a lot of physio recovery working on my body and my strength and my movements, compared to the first three months in ICU where I was just sitting in pain and couldn’t breathe, eat or drink.“The journey itself is a dficult one and there is still a long way to go but I am optimistic for the future.”Solo recovered enough of his speech to send a message to his country’s rugby stars as they lted the World Cup and was also visited in hospital by England cricket star Ben Stokes.A fundraiser to send Solo home, set up by his agent Rob Humphries, has so far raised more than £, and Solo expressed his gratitude to those who have helped his cause so far.He said: “I am incredibly grateful. I could never have imagined receiving the amount of support I have throughout me being sick.“I am truly humbled and very grateful for all the support everyone has given me throughout this disease.”To donate to the fundraiser visit gf.me v c gfm oinhaelc

title: 12 months on from new aberdeen deal its sam cosgrove who deserves all the credit for rise
story: Exactly a year ago today Sam Cosgrove signed a contract extension tying him to Pittodrie until summer .Viewed  months on, tying up the striker’s long-term future was a masterstroke from the Aberdeen board.It would now take a multi-million-pound bid to force the Dons’ hand to sell a player who cost just £, in January .That could be tested this month as Middlesbrough, Derby County and Stoke are all tracking the -year-old.Prolic scoring does not go unnoticed and Aberdeen are braced for any approach or bid from England for Cosgrove this month.McInnes hailed the role head of recruitment Russ Richardson played in highlighting the then-unknown Carlisle United reserve player.He also acknowledged the Dons and the club’s coaching staff for giving Cosgrove the  to thrive.But ultimately it is the player, who netted  goals in , who is responsible for becoming one of the hottest strikers in Scotland.McInnes said: “Sam came to a club that could make him stronger, better and more confident.“All my staff have played a part in that.“My head of recruitment, Russ Richardson, also deserves so much praise for identying Sam.“When Russ watched Sam he liked how he received the ball and liked how he moved.“But ultimately Sam’s rise is not down to Russ, the staff or myself.“It is Sam who deserves the most for actually making the most of his opportunity. He relished the opportunity at Aberdeen and played the biggest part himself.”Officially Cosgrove netted  goals in  but the striker also netted a further two just days after penning his new deal.He scored both goals in Aberdeen’s - friendly win over United Arab Emirates’ side Dibba Al-Hisn in a friendly in Dubai last January.Cosgrove suffered a shaky start to his time at Aberdeen when sent off in his debut against Celtic on February  .He would have to wait  months since signing for his first goal when netting a double in a - defeat of St Mirren in October.That December he hit the goal trail, netting in five straight games to bag seven goals.McInnes insists they were looking for an alternative to prolic striker Adam Rooney. That December proved they had found one.Aberdeen then moved quickly to tie him up on a long-term deal beyond the contract that ran until summer .McInnes said: “We were looking for an alternative striker to Adam Rooney who we could work with and try to make better.“Jayden Stockley had obviously been with us but we knew we could maybe sell him back into England.“Jayden was maybe getting a bit frustrated that he wasn’t always playing ahead of Adam.“We wanted somebody a bit dferent with a bit of size.“When we first signed him that was something we spoke about but also to not be too dependent on his size in and around the box, to be a sharper striker and concentrate more on movement, positioning and anticipation rather than just letting the ball hit your head.“So thatteams sit in at home and want to defend their box, we have a striker there we can put in the box.“Sam has learned to use his size a lot better since being here.“He has relished the opportunity.”Cosgrove’s prolic scoring streak quickly caught the imagination of the Aberdeen supporters.They began chanting “Sam Cosgrove Ballon d’Or” at games in recognition of the successor to Rooney, who hit -plus goals for three successive season.Cosgrove has already smashed in  goals this season and became the first Aberdeen player to reach that milestone since Duncan Shearer in .He was denied the opportunity to add to that tally by a two-game ban for the final two games before the winter shutdown for a challenge on Celtic defender Kristoffer Ajer.Aberdeen appealed the straight red, arguing Cosgrove clearly won the ball, but the red and the ban were upheld.McInnes said: “There is no doubt that once Sam became really accepted by the supporters that meant so much to him.“For any young player,they know the supporters, the staff the players and the manager are behind him it means so much.“But particularly to know the supporters are right behind you because you can respond to that.“Sam has certainly responded.”

title: st johnstone boss tommy wright expects matty kennedy to join aberdeen
story: St Johnstone manager Tommy Wright believes that Matty Kennedy will sign a pre-contract agreement with Aberdeen.The Perth boss hasn’t given up all hope that the former Kilmarnock winger can be persuaded the Pittodrie grass isn’t greener than McDiarmid Park’s but fears the worst.“Derekhas kept me informed about Matty and I think they have now made him an offer,” said Wright.“We are putting an offer to him as well because I don’t want to lose him.“But hand on heart, I don’t think we will be able to keep him.“I think he will go to Aberdeen.“I hope I am wrong and will keep encouraging him to stay and the club to keep him.“But with Aberdeen in for him, I think that’s what will happen.”Wright hopes that lessons will have been learned about the best time to try and secure star players on long-term deals.“I will be speaking to Kirstenabout it because we have to protect our assets better,” he said.“For a club of our size we have to move earlier because that’s when we have the advantage.“Matty had been in the wilderness. He came here, enjoyed his football and the time for us to strike would have been last year.“Last January would have been the time to sit down with him and get him signed up on a longer contract.“When it becomes this late, the financial muscle other clubs have comes into play and that is totally understandable.“We can’t compete with clubs who have two or three times our budget. It’s a simple fact of le.“I don’t think it’s something which will drag on, but I don’t want to lose him in the window.”

title: meet rg mowat owner of the fulmar
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAt the end of November we asked readers for help to unravel the mystery of a yacht log book which was posted to the paper with no clues as to its origin.And, not for the first time, Argyllshire Advertiser readers have come up trumps and we now know a little more about the boat#s owner, named only as RG Mowat in the log book.The  log book gives an account of the voyages of the -foot gaff cutter #Fulmar# and the adventures of her colourful crew. Its dog-eared pages contain neatly-typed records, precise drawings and fascinating photographs.The log#s mystery is deepened by the fact no names are given other than the nicknames #Tanky#, #Bosun#, #Skipper# and #Pilot#. The only crew member named is pet dachshund #Major#.The log does record the Fulmar#s home port was Tighnabruaich and the owner was RG Mowat, but few details on Mr Mowat could be found.Lord Weir of Lochhead, Achahoish, contacted the newspaper to pass on information on Commander Ralph G Mowat.During the Second World War, Commander Mowat was a Royal Navy Captain, latterly in command of a cruiser. At the end of the war, he and his ship entered Copenhagen, where he took the surrender of the German troops.Clive Brown from Ardfern added some post-war detail. He revealed: #Commander Ralph G Mowat, RN , was a distinguished member of Clyde Cruising Clubbest known as being, for  years, the honorary editor of the CCC Sailing Directions . These were # and indeed remain # a #must have# for everyone who navigates their way among the many lochs and islands of Scotland#s west coast. They were colloquially known as the #Blue Book# and published at that time as a hardback. He also served as CCC Rear Commodore -.#Mr Brown also provided an extract from the book #Clyde Cruising Club, The First One Hundred Years -# which states Ralph Mowat received an RYA Award for services to yachting in  but refused to accept honorary membership of the club. In recompense, his widow Mary was elected an honorary member in , after his death.Tighnabruaich man Alan Wilson contacted Clyde sailing legend Ian Nicolson, who was fairly sure he recalled racing against the #Fulmar# in the s.Mr Nicolson said:#Old Man Mowat, as I remember him, was a typical ex Royal Navy officer. He treated me as a young upstart, which I was, but we got on well because I wrote a bit for Clyde Cruising Club publications. He lived in Clarkston on the edge of Glasgow.#Clyde Cruising Club itself cannot help with information on the Fulmar. Club secretary Jenner Rollands contacted the Advertiser and confirmed CCC sadly lost all its records when the Carrick, moored on the River Clyde, sank in . At the time, the club#s office was aboard her.Closer to home, Ardrishaig man Billy Paterson called into the Advertiser offices to say his father, Ardrishaig Primary School headmaster Gilbert Paterson, had crewed the yacht Fulmar.Mr Paterson still has mementoes from his father#s trips in the form of gts from Commander Mowat, including a paperweight from , a copper and brass barrel ashtray dated  and a brass model yacht with #Fulmar # engraved on it.Thanks to everyone who contacted the Advertiser with their memories.We now know a little more about Commander Ralph G Mowat, RN , owner of the Fulmar.Details about the crew of #Tanky#, #Bosun# and #Pilot# remain, however, sketchy, soanyone out there knows any more#

story: Rachel CarruthersUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsThe Scottish Salmon Companyhas provided Cowal Badminton Association with funding towards new sporting equipment following its latest round of Community Fund awards.Cowal Badminton Association received a £ donation to cover the costs of rackets and shuttlecocks for their new practice nights.The association was founded almost  years ago, playing a vital role in bringing the community of Dunoon together by offering weekly social events that are inclusive to all.Development co-ordinator at Cowal Badminton Association, Craig Anderson, said: #The funding from SSC has enabled us to purchase new rackets and tubes of shuttlecocks, which our members will be able to use. On behalf of the team, we thank the Scottish Salmon Company for its kind donation.#Volunteers are being offered a chance to work off some of the seasonal over eating, as a work party is held at Tarbert Castle.Meeting at am tomorrow , the group will set about planting trees and removing brambles until around lunchtime.The perfect opportunity to catch up following the festivities, all willing to help will be made welcome and tea and coffee will be on offer to the hard working volunteers.A #Scandinavian# approach to self-sufficiency is being proposed by Craignish Community Council.With Argyll and Bute Council being unable extend their gritting areas, community council members picked up bags of grit from the council depot.
