title: record-numbers-waiting-12-hours-scotlands-e-units
story: Experts have blamed cuts in hospital beds and a collapse in GP and social care services in the community for the crisis, as the latest weekly figures revealed that , patients spent more than  hours in emergency departments in December , compared to  in December  and just  in December .Camleys Cartoon: AE waitsThe increases far outstrip the rise in AE attendance, which has climbed by  per cent from just over , in December  to just under , last month.It comes as the AE statistics for November also reveal that only .% of patients were seen, treated and either admitted or discharged within the four-hour target, well short of the Scottish Governments % benchmark.: Three in four doctors say work pressures are harming their own healthDr David Chung, vice president of Royal College of Emergency MedicineScotland said a lack of available hospital beds meant more patients requiring admission were stuck longer in AE.He said: ldquoWe are now witnessing record levels of eight hour and  hour waits in Scotlandrsquos emergency departments.ldquoPoor performance cannot be solely linked to increasing attendances, therersquos clearly an urgent need to build capacity in the system through restoring the number of staffed beds and building a primary and social care system that meets the demand of Scotlandrsquos growing and ageing society.ldquoLong waits mean patients on trolleys and care delivered on corridors. We must do better by our patients."In the past decade, the number of beds in NHS Scotland has been cut by nearly a fth, from , to ,.Dr Helene Irvine, a public health consultant who retired from NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde last year, said she believes the reduction in beds in Scotlands largest health board has been too sharp during a period of growing demand.NHS GGC has reduced its bed numbers by .%, to , last year, but around % of its hospital admissions are patients referred for specialist treatment or procedures from other health boards such as Forth Valley, Highland and Dumfries and Galloway."You have to bear that in mind when youre calculating your bed requirements," said Dr Irvine. "I think they probably dont have enough beds now based on how much work theyre doing. You have all these elderly people from GGC, then you have all these extra people coming in from other health boards."Compliance with the four-hour AE target was consistently below % for NHS GGC throughout December.For Scotland as a whole, , patients spent more than eight hours in AE in December , compared to an average of  in the previous four Decembers, from  to .: What the boy on the floor case really tells us about the NHSThe picture was even starker in relation to the numbers waiting more than  hours, which were , last month compared to an average of  for Decembers -.Dr Irvine said the deterioration in AE performance dates back to , when many councils responded to budget cuts by reducing funding for elderly social care.However, her own research also shows that AE dips are clearly linked to a spike in attendance by better-off, elderly patients.She said: "In GGC and other parts of the west of Scotland, what I found was that in the weeks when we had very poor compliance with the four-hour, eight-hour or -hour AE waiting times, we also had a spike in the elderly-affluent."They come in, theyre demanding, there isnt maybe that much wrong with them, but their children dont want to take them home and theyre putting pressure on staff to admit them. A lot of time is spent to-ing and fro-ing in the AE to decide what to do with them."That can easily endup being a four-hour, or an eight-hour or a -hour breach."This is one of the reasons I tell people not to get so hung up on AE compliance. Invest in social care for the elderly, in general practice, in district nurses. What you need are community-based staff to deal with all this."Miles Briggs, Scottish Conservative health spokesman, said: ldquoThese signicant increases in the numbers of patients waiting an extreme amount of time in AE are truly shocking.ldquoIt is particularly dreadful that these waiting times are so long when average attendance hasnrsquot changed very much at all.Monica Lennon, Scottish Labourrsquos health spokeswoman, added: ldquoEmergency medicine experts have been warning for months about a lack of preparedness in our NHS for winter pressures. No one should have to spend half a day in AE and these worrying trends canrsquot continue."A Scottish Government spokesman said: ldquoScotlandrsquos core AE departments continue to be the best performing in the UK and have been for more than four and a half years despite experiencing continued high attendance levels.ldquoTo support the impact that winter pressures can have on performance, we have invested a further pound. million bringing the total additional investment to pound.mto ensure quality of care, patient safety and access to services are maintained over the winter period."This is in addition to the pound.mpreviously allocated to support unscheduled care throughout the year."

title: community-ownership-surges-highlands
story: Now a Highland constituency has been found to have the joint highest number of community-owned assets in Scotland, according to a new government report.As of December , Skye, Lochaber and Badenoch had  community assets owned by  dferent groups.While Argyll and Bute had the same number of assets, its neighbour to the north boasted ownership over a much wider area - nearly , hectares compared to only ,.The figure for Skye, Lochaber and Badenoch also marks an increase of over , hectares over the past  months.In terms of land mass, the Western Islesdwarfs the combined Highland region , as the Na h-Eileanan an Iar constituency has  community-owned assets by  groups.Across Scotland there has been an increase in community-land ownership, but the national total - , hectares - makes up less than three per cent of the total land area of the country.The SNPrsquos Kate Forbes, MSP for Skye, Lochaber and Badenoch, said she was ldquoencouraged to see that her constituency has the joint highest number of community-owned assets in Scotland, adding: ldquoI sincerely hope the increase in community land ownership will continue.She said: ldquoLand reform is a means to an end ndash an end where communities are in control of their own destinies. Time and time again I see examples of communities being thrown this way and that because they donrsquot have a stake in a signicant local initiative, in local land or in other local assets.ldquoBut, equally, community ownership itself is never the final destination. It is about what you do with land reform or community ownership that really matters. To achieve that, wersquove got to support communities with the expertise, guidance and advice they need.ldquoFor the Highlands to thrive, we need to support interventions that will really act as a catalyst for a thriving population. That has got to include land reform, but that has got to go in tandem with other forms of support. If land reform is the bedrock, then housing, infrastructure and connectivity are the building blocks of a sustainable community.ldquoEvery community is dferent, and the notion of community ownership means that local owners can respond to local need. In some communities, theyrsquove been doing that for years. Elsewhere, they are just starting.A champion of land reform as a means to unlock the potential of communities and help stem the depopulation of Highland areas, Ms Forbes addressed the Community Land Scotland conference in June, telling delegates that, while land reform is well supported in terms of financial and legal powers, the volunteers who spearhead changes need support, training and guidance.In August, the first community-owned school in the constituency was opened by John Swinney.Strontian Primary School, on the Ardnamurchan peninsula in the Highlands, was built after the community of around  people rejected Highland Councilrsquos plans to improve their old primary school building.Local residents raised around pound, towards the project, with cash coming from the community-owned hydro scheme as well as donations.The school building was jointly funded by a commercial loan from Triodos Bank, a payment for tenantsrsquo works from Highland Council, a community share offer which raised more than pound,, and pound, in grants from the Scottish Land Fund and Foundation Scotland.The community buy-out of Eigg, in the Inner Hebrides, saw a trust take ownership of the km by km island in  after paying pound. million, aided by a poundm gt from an anonymous donor. The success of the community ownership now serves as a model for other islands after it hit a population milestone  years after the buyout.

title: iran-launches-missiles-us-bases-iraq
story: President Donald Trump insisted ldquoAll is well! after Iran fired surface-to-surface missiles at two Iraqi bases housing US troops.He promised to make a statement to the nation on Wednesday morning about the increasingly precarious situation with Iran.Mr Trump offered no immediate indication of whether he would retaliate, and stayed out of sight as news of the missile strikes emerged.:Donald Trump threatens Iranian cultural sites despite war crime concernsBut he tweeted that an assessment of casualties and damages was under way. The initial outlook, he said, was ldquoSo far, so good!Iran struck back at the US for the killing of a top Iranian general, firing a series of ballistic missiles at two Iraqi bases housing US troops in Iraq.Iranian state TV said it was in revenge for the US killing of Revolutionary Guard General Qassem Soleimani, whose death last week in an American drone strike near Baghdad prompted calls for avenge.All is well! Missiles launched from Iran at two military bases located in Iraq. Assessment of casualties  damages taking place now. So far, so good! We have the most powerful and well equipped military anywhere in the world, by far! I will be making a statement tomorrow morning.mdash Donald J. TrumpJanuary , Gen Soleimanirsquos killing and the strikes by Iran came as tensions have been rising steadily across the Middle East after President Donald Trumprsquos decision to unilaterally withdraw America from Tehranrsquos nuclear deal with world powers.They also marked the first time in recent years that Washington and Tehran have attacked each other directly rather than through proxies in the region. It raised the chances of open conflict erupting between the two enemies, which have been at odds since Iranrsquos  Islamic Revolution.Iran initially announced only one strike, but US officials confirmed both.US defence officials were at the White House, probably to discuss options with Mr Trump, who launched the strike on Soleimani while facing an upcoming impeachment trial in the Senate.Iranrsquos Revolutionary Guard warned the US and its regional allies against retaliating over the missile attack against the Ain al-Asad air base in Iraqrsquos western Anbar province. The Guard issued the warning via a statement carried by Iranrsquos state-run IRNA news agency.:Analysis: Trump knows Iran weakness will hamper re-election oddsldquoWe are warning all American allies, who gave their bases to its terrorist army, that any territory that is the starting point of aggressive acts against Iran will be targeted, it said. It also threatened Israel.After the strikes, a former Iranian nuclear negotiator posted a picture of the Islamic Republicrsquos flag on Twitter, appearing to mimic Mr Trump who posted an American flag following the killing of Gen Soleimani and others on Friday in a drone strike in Baghdad.Ain al-Asad air base was first used by American forces after the  US-led invasion that toppled dictator Saddam Hussein, and later saw American troops stationed there amid the fight against the Islamic State group in Iraq and Syria. It houses about , US and coalition forces.Two Iraqi security officials said at least one of the missiles appeared to have struck a plane at the base, igniting a fire. It was not immediately clear whether it was an Iraqi or US jet.About  Norwegian troops also were on the air base but no injuries were reported, Brynjar Stordal, a spokesperson for the Norwegian Armed Forces told the Associated Press.Mr Trump visited the sprawling Ain al-Asad air base, about  miles west of Baghdad, in December , making his first presidential visit to troops in the region.He did not meet with any Iraqi officials at the time, and his visit inflamed sensitivities about the continued presence of US forces in Iraq. Vice President Mike Pence also has visited the base.Iranian state TV said the Guardrsquos aerospace ision that controls Iranrsquos missile program launched the attack, which it said was part of an operation called Martyr Soleimani.The US also acknowledged another missile attack on a base in Irbil in Iraqrsquos semi-autonomous Kurdish region.ldquoAs we evaluate the situation and our response, we will take all necessary measures to protect and defend US personnel, partners and allies in the region, said Jonathan Hoffman, an assistant to the US defence secretary.Wednesdayrsquos revenge attack happened just hours after crowds in Iran mourned Gen Soleimani at his funeral. It also came as the US continued to reinforce its own positions in the region and warned of an unspecied threat to shipping from Iran in the regionrsquos waterways, crucial routes for global energy supplies.US embassies and consulates from Asia to Africa and Europe issued security alerts for Americans.A stampede broke out Tuesday at Gen Soleimanirsquos funeral, and at least  people were killed and more than  injured as thousands thronged the procession, Iranian news reports said.The stampede took place in Gen Soleimanirsquos hometown of Kerman as his coffin was being borne through the city in south-eastern Iran, said Pirhossein Koulivand, head of Iranrsquos emergency medical services.ldquoUnfortunately as a result of the stampede, some of our compatriots have been injured and some have been killed during the funeral processions, Mr Koulivand said, and state TV quoted him as saying that  had died and  had been injured.Gen Soleimanirsquos burial was delayed, with no new time given, because of concerns about the huge crowd at the cemetery, the semi-official ISNA news agency said.Meanwhile, everyone on board a Ukrainian aircraft carrying around  passengers and crew that crashed close to Iranrsquos capital, Tehran, has died, Iranian state television has reported.The plane had taken off from Imam Khomeini International Airport, the report said.It went down in farmland outside of the city.Authorities initially blamed a mechanical problem for the crash.

title: there-consequences-leaving-eu-says-ursula-von-der-leyen
story: She told an audience at the London School of Economics, where she formerly studied, that many of the principles of the EU and the single market had been guided by British figures.Ms von der Leyen said January  ndash Britainrsquos exit day ndash would be a ldquotough and emotional day but insisted that theties between the UK and the European Union will continue to be ldquounbreakable even after Brexit.Addressing the crowd she said there would be ldquotough talks ahead between the UK and the EU.She told her audience at the London School of Economics: ldquoYou can choose collaboration over isolation, you can shape your continentrsquos destiny, you can hold your governments accountable, you can refuse to be satisfied with the status quo and can turn things into how they should be.ldquoI know the last few years have been dficult and isive. I hope that by being constructive and ambitious in the upcoming negotiations, we can all move forward together.ldquoThere will be tough talks ahead and each side will do what is best for them.ldquoBut I can assure you that the United Kingdom will always have a trusted friend and partner in the European Union.:MSPs urged to reject Brexit dealShe added: ldquoWhen the sun rises again on February , the United Kingdom and the European Union will still be the best of friends and partners.ldquoThe bonds between us will still be unbreakable."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Brexit:  days until Britain is scheduled to leave the EU","description": "Brexit:  days until Britain is scheduled to leave the EU","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media bZTeQW poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests bZTeQW.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Ms von der Leyen said there would be ldquoconsequences to leaving the EU and that the UK would have to accept compromises.ldquoOur partnership cannot and will not be the same as before, she said in her speech on Wednesday.ldquoIt will not be as close as before because with every choice comes a consequence. With every decision, comes a trade-off.ldquoWithout the free movement of people, you cannot have the free movement of capital, goods and services.:Boris Johnson renews push to get his Brexit deal through ParliamentldquoWithout a level playing field on environment, labour and state aid, you cannot have the highest quality access to the worldrsquos largest single market.ldquoThe more ergence there is, the more distant the partnership will be.Ms von derLeyen said the EU and Britain would have to prioritise when negotiatingthe Government was not willing to extend the transition period beyond December.ldquoWithout an extension of the transition period beyond , you cannot expect to agree on every single aspect of our new partnership, she warned.ldquoWe will have to prioritise.And she added: ldquoWe are prepared to design a new partnership with zero tarfs, zero quotas, zero dumping ndash a partnership that goes well beyond trade and is unprecedented in scope.

title: alister-jack-confirms-recieved-nicola-sturgeons-request-second-independence-referendum
story: Speaking during Scotland questions, Mr Jack was quick, however, to refute SNP MPrsquos calls for a new vote.Airdrie and Shotts MP Neil Gray questioned the Governmentrsquos decision to refuse the poll.:SNP minister warns against lsquoundemocratic power grabrsquo by WestminsterHe said: ldquoHis party enjoys % of the vote to deliver Brexit and yet denies the SNP its right to give the people of Scotland its say with the % of the vote in Scotland that we have secured.Mr Jack replied: ldquoThe First Minister has asked for the right to set referendums in the future, to decide the context of those.ldquoWe are very clear about this. Constitutional matters are reserved and it would be completely wrong for us to hands those powers over to the Scottish Parliament because we would end up in a series of never-endums.The SNPrsquos deputy Westminster leader Kirsty Blackman accused the Government of ignoring Scottish voters.She said: ldquoThe UK Government has ignored Scottish peoplersquos voices and votes in every election and referendum since , careering on with both Brexit and austerity.:SNP make changes to frontbench team at WestminsterldquoCan the Secretary of State inform us what precise electoral event would convince him that Scotland people should have the right to choose their own future Mr Jack replied: ldquoRegarding whether the time will be right, both Nicola Sturgeon and Alex Salmond at the time said it was a lsquoonce-in-a-generation, once-in-a-letime decisionrsquo.ldquoI donrsquot feel a generation or a letime has passed.Mr Jackrsquos predecessor as Scottish secretary, David Mundell, called on the First Minister to accept the result of the  referendum.Mr Mundell said: ldquoDoes he agree with me though that this document is just another expensive and time-wasting stunt by Nicola Sturgeon and the SNP ldquoThe people of Scotland chose, they chose in  decisively to remain in the UK and itrsquos time Nicola Sturgeon and the SNP accepted that and move on.Mr Jack paid tribute to Mr Mundellrsquos  years as a spokesman on Scottish affairs.He said: ldquoItrsquos quite clear that the Scottish Government constantly harp on about independence and separation because they want to deflect from the main issue and the main issue is that they are failing in our school standards and they are failing our NHS.

title: relationship-westminster-holyrood-at-low-ebb

Ministerial Committee, Mr Russell said:ldquoThere has been scant,any, respect for the devolved administrations, very little,any, for the devolved competencies and a view that when push comes to shove the UK Government can do precisely what it wishes to do.He ascribed some of the blame to the ldquoconsiderable nervousness within the UKrsquos civil service about what is taking place and how itrsquos taking place and said: ldquoItrsquos fair to say that normal relationships which Irsquove been used to as a minister these last  years are at a low ebb from officials as well as ministers.The Prime Ministerrsquos Withdrawal Agreement would give Westminster powers over devolved areas but the Scottish Government said they only learned of the Billrsquos details the day before its publication.Addressing comments from the UK Government thanking Holyrood for its input to the Bill, Mr Russell said: ldquoThey say that they work with the devolved administrations aseverything was wonderful ndash it isnrsquot wonderful.:Alister Jack confirms he has received Nicola Sturgeonrsquos request for a second independence referendumldquoItrsquos an extraordinarily dficult set of relations that have got even worse since the Johnson Government got elected.Mr Russell was asked by the SNPrsquosAngela Constance about problems for EU citizens in the UK who are ldquohaving to apply for rights they already have.Arguing there are practical problems with the settled status scheme as well as ethical concerns, Mr Russell said: ldquoThis isnrsquot a particularly well-run scheme and itrsquos producing results that are unacceptable for some people.ldquoBut therersquos the political and moral objection to people who have spent some of them their entire working lives in this country as citizens working alongside all of us and are now being told they will only have the right to staythey go through this process which they find offensive.He also raised concerns about the Withdrawal Agreementrsquos apparent changes in Clause  that would mean courts are no longer bound by previous judgements by European Courts.Citing the Scottish Governmentrsquos Fair Work agenda as being ldquobased upon the rights and protections that exist in the European Union, Mr Russell warned the UK Government wants to ldquocut and remove workersrsquo rights.He said: ldquoThe reality of the situation is this will undermine workersrsquo rights and protections, human rights will be undermined and environmental rights will be undermined.ldquoI donrsquot think therersquos any doubt about it.

title: alister-jack-refuses-handing-power-holyrood-indy-polls-saying-lead-neverendums
story: In a fractious Scottish Questions in the Commons, the Scottish Secretary was bombarded with questions on indyref from the SNP benches.When he took five questions together on the issue of the Scottish Governmentrsquos publication, Scotlandrsquos Right to Choose, Mr Jack quipped to Tory laughter: ldquoTherersquos no independence of thought in the questions.First up, Chris Law, the MP for Dundee West, mocked the Secretary of State, saying he had told Scottish voters repeatedly in the election campaign about how a vote for the Tories would be a vote to stop another independence referendum and noted how that ldquowent well, given the governing party had lost half their Scottish seats and had ldquobarely a rump of MPs.:Alister Jack confirms he has received Nicola Sturgeonrsquos request for a second independence referendumStressing how the SNP had won  per cent of Scottish seats in the December election, Mr Law insisted, to hear-hears from his colleagues, that Scottish voters had, by doing so, expressed their ldquodemocratic will to choose their own future.Mr Jack emphasised how  per cent of Scots voted for the SNP in the election and the same proportion had voted for independence in . To more barracking from the SNP benches, he declared: ldquoThe numbers simply have not changed.ldquoBack in , the independence referendum came on the back of something called the Edinburgh Agreement, which was signed by Alex Salmond and Nicola Sturgeon, the then deputy leader, and in the agreement it said both parties would respect the outcome of the referendum and that hasnrsquot happened.The SNPrsquos Amy Callaghan, the new MP for East Dunbartonshire, accused the Government of a ldquoblinding contradiction ie it claimed to have a mandate to implement Brexit on the back of a  per cent share of the vote but that the Scottish Government did not have one to hold a second referendum on the back of a  per cent share.Mr Jack replied: ldquoIt was a referendum three years ago. We are speaking for the majority of ScotshellipWe are absolutely respecting that decision whereas the SNP are not respecting it and want to tear up the UK.Nationalist MP Neil Gray, who represents Airdrie and Shotts, claimed Mr Jackrsquos performance had demonstrated how untenable the Governmentrsquos position was on indyref, repeating the  per cent  per cent argument.To encouragement from colleagues, he asked: ldquoWhat is his democratic case for denying the people of Scotland their democratic right to choose Mr Jack, who noted how Ms Sturgeonrsquos letter to Boris Johnson of December  would be replied to ldquoin due course, told MPs the FM had asked for the right to set referendums in the future.ldquoWe are very clear about this, he insisted, ldquoconstitutional matters are reserved. It would be completely wrong for us to hand those powers over to the Scottish Parliament because we would end up in a series of neverendums bad for the Scottish, bad for Scottish jobs, reducing tax income and, therefore, damaging already failing public services.One Whitehall source later told The Herald: ldquoIt would be completely irresponsible to hand over the power on referendums as it would paralyse Scotland and Scotlandrsquos economy.In the chamber, Kirsty Blackman, the SNP deputy leader at Westminster, who the party said had taken on the prime constitutional role ldquoin preparation for an independence referendum, claimed the Government had ignored Scottish peoplersquos voices and votes since , ldquocareering on with both Brexit and austerity.She asked Mr Jack what electoral event would convince him that Scotlandrsquos people should have the right to choose their own future.:Relationship between Westminster and Holyrood lsquoat low ebbrsquoThe Scottish Secretary picked up on the austerity issue, saying: ldquoThe Scottish Governmentrsquos own independence figures show there would be a pound.bn hole in the Scottish finances and that would mean real austerity.ldquoRegarding when the time would be right, both Nicola Sturgeon and Alex Salmond said it was a once-in-a-generation, a once-in-a-letime decision. I donrsquot feel a generation or letime have passed.David Mundell, Mr Jackrsquos predecessor at the Scotland Office, said the Scottish Governmentrsquos Right To Choose document was ldquojust another expensive and time-wasting stunt by Nicola Sturgeon and the SNP.He went on: ldquoThe people of Scotland chose in  decisively to remain in the UK and itrsquos time Nicola Sturgeon and the SNP accepted that and moved on.During his tenure at Dover House, the Dumfriesshire MP took Scottish Questions  times.

title: airlines-begin-rerouting-flights-amid-escalating-middle-east-tensions
story: The UK has urged Iran not to carry out further ldquoreckless and dangerous attacks after Tehran fired missiles at military bases in Iraq hosting British and US troops.British Airways rerouted flight  from Mumbai to Heathrow mid-way through the flight, to avoid crossing Iraqi airspace. The plane flew in a circle and was then erted to the Greek capital Athens for refuelling.:Trump knows Iran weakness will hamper re-election oddsThe move has left a number of Indian passport holders stuck in the terminal as they do not possess the right visa to leave the airport.One passenger, who asked not to be named, told the PA news agency that Indian nationals had been stuck in the terminal for a number of hours.He said: ldquoSince we donrsquot have Schengen visa, BA couldnrsquot put us in hotels which are outside the airport. Athens staff are doing their best to find alternate BA flights for us but looks like  odd passengers couldnrsquot be accommodated.ldquoSo either we will be put on other flights or  have to spend the night at the terminal lounge.He said the flight, which took off more than  hours ago, had been rescheduled to Thursday morning.British Airways said: ldquoWe appreciate the frustrating situation that a handful of our customers are in, without visas to enter Greece, following the ersion.ldquoWe have apologised to our customers for the delay to their travel plans and our colleagues are doing everything they can to rebook customers, and take care of them until their flight departs.Virgin Atlantic said it is ldquoclosely monitoring the situation and its aircraft are not flying over Iranian airspace. Due to changes in flight routing, trips to and from Mumbai may take longer than expected.Australian carrier Qantas said it is altering its route from London to Perth, Australia, to avoid Iranian and Iraqi airspace until further notice.Malaysia Airlines and Singapore Airlines have also rerouted planes to avoid Iranian airspace.The US Federal Aviation Administration has barred American pilots and carriers from flying in areas of Iraqi, Iranian and some Persian Gulf airspace while the Russian aviation agency has recommended all Russian airlines avoid flying over Iran, Iraq, the Persian Gulf and the Gulf of Oman.:Iran launches missiles at US bases in IraqForeign Secretary Dominic Raab has urged Iran to pursue ldquourgent de-escalation as the crisis in the Gulf intensies.US President Donald Trump tweeted ldquoall is well following the attack on the bases, which was carried out in response to the killing of Iranian General Qassem Soleimani by America.US officials said  missiles were fired, with  striking the Ain al-Asad base  miles west of Baghdad, one striking a base in Irbil in northern Iraqrsquos semi-autonomous Kurdish region, and another four missing their targets.

title: zara-tindall-faces-six-month-driving-ban-91mph-speeding-offence
story: The -year-old royal pleaded guilty to driving her Land Rover at mph on the A in Gloucestershire, violating the mph speed limit.The offence took place on November  last year.The mother-of-two, who is married to former Gloucester and England rugby player Mike Tindall, was issued with four points on her licence and as a result of exceeding the -point maximum now faces an automatic six-month driving ban.: Ministers announce Airbnb crackdown in ScotlandShe had already accumulated nine penalty points on her licence as a result of three previous offences in February , February  and December .These were for speeding, a fixed penalty offence and a traffic signal penalty.Gloucestershire Police operate a frequent road safety patrol from a lay-by at Dartley Bottom - a long, straight stretch of the road between Gloucester and Cirencester, where they catch hundreds of drivers a year.Prosecutor Farley Turner said: "Because Mrs Tindall already has nine points on her licence she was unable to accept a fixed penalty for this offence.": Scotland wont be riding to Labours rescue thhis time aroundRoger Utley, chairman of the bench at Cheltenham Magistrates Court, announced that as well as the six-month ban the court was fining Mrs Tindall pound plus costs and a victim surcharge of pound.Her mother Princess Anne was caught speeding on the same stretch of road in .Ms Tindall is currently on holiday in Australia and was not present for the court hearing.

title: harry-meghan-step-back-senior-royals
story: The royal couple, who have just ed from a six-week break staying at a pound. million waterfront mansion in Canadas Vancouver Island with eight-month-old son Archie, said they also wanted to "work to become financially independent".In a bombshell announcement, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex - who wed in  - said they had taken the decision after "many months of reflection".: Zara Tindall banned from driving over new speeding offenceIn a statement, the couple said: "After many months of reflection and internal discussions, we have chosen to make a transition this year in starting to carve out a progressive new role within this institution."We intend to step back as senior members of the Royal Family and work to become financially independent, while continuing to fully support Her Majesty The Queen."It is with your encouragement, particularly over the last few years, that we feel prepared to make this adjustment."We now plan to balance our time between the United Kingdom and North America, continuing to honour our duty to the Queen, the Commonwealth, and our patronages."The couple already have signicant personal wealth, but it is not considered likely that the Queen, or later the Prince of Wales, would cut off Prince Harry and Meghan eventhey were to move overseas full-time.Princes William and Harry are granted pound million a year in total by the Queen from the taxpayer-funded Sovereign Grant.The brothers can also claim pound.m a year for non-official expenditure, while Prince Harry has additional income of around poundm annually for staffing costs and receives a further pound.m a year approximately from his fathers Duchy of Cornwall estate.The security bill for the Sussex family, eventhey do move abroad, has been put at an estimated pound,-a-year for taxpayers.The announcementfollowed mounting speculation that the couple were planning to relocate to Canada after a controversial year which saw them criticised over taxpayer-funded renovations to their Frogmore House home in Windsor and their participation in an ITV documentary where they spoke of the pressures of royal le and press scrutiny.: Ive seen for myself the good that the Royal Family can doIn an interview with ITVs Tom Brady during a royal tour of South Africa in October, Meghan said not many people had askedshe was okay and admitted living in the public eye as a new mother had been a "struggle".Critics said it struck the wrong note, coming against a backdrop of visits to poverty-stricken slums.During the same -day tour, the couple also caused shockwaves when they announced that Meghan was suing the Mail on Sunday for breaches ofand data protection law over the publication of a handwritten letter to her from her estranged father.Days later, Prince Harry also launched legal proceedings against the owners of the Sun and Daily Mirror newspapers over alleged phone hacking.The decision to spend part of their time living and working overseas has been seen by some commentators as a bid to escape the spotlight of the British media while they bring up their son, who was born in April.Their statement added: "This geographic balance will enable us to raise our son with an appreciation for the royal tradition into which he was born, while also providing our family with the space to focus on the next chapter, including the launch of our new charitable entity."We look forward to sharing the full details of this exciting next step in due course, as we continue to collaborate with Her Majesty The Queen, The Prince of Wales, The Duke of Cambridge and all relevant parties."Until then, please accept our deepest thanks for your continued support."However, a statement from Buckingham Palace said discussions were still "at an early stage" and "complicated", prompting speculation that theDuke and Duchess may have rushed out their own statement prematurely.A spokesman for Buckingham Palace said: ldquoDiscussions with the Duke  Duchess of Sussex are at an early stage."We understand their desire to take a dferent approach, but these are complicated issues that will take their time to work through.Prince Harry is now sixth in line to the throne after his father Prince Charles, brother Prince William, and Prince Williams three children.As a result, he has more freedom to choose his own path away from palace le and royal duties.The decision to split their time across the Atlantic was seen by commentators as an attempt to secure more privacy for the couple, as well as allowing American national Meghan - who grew up in Calornia and worked as an actress in the series Suits, shot in Toronto, prior to marrying Harry - more time in her homeland.It is expected that their son, Archie, will hold dual British-American nationality.Rhiannon Mills, royal correspondent for Sky News, said it shows "the pressure that they were under" and that Harry is in a "dferent phase of his le".She added that Harry has always had a "dficult relationship with the press since his mother died", but having a we and son has "changed the dynamic of what he wants to do as a working royal".Not everyone was pleased, however. Good Morning Britain presenter Piers Morgan said Meghan had "ditched her family" and had now "split [Prince Harry] from the Royal Family".

title: scenic-stirling-marathon-returns-new-guise
story: And now whether running through a desire for fitness or to raise cash for a worthy cause, people across Scotland and throughout the UK will make good on their New Yearrsquos resolutions and enter what is described as one of the worldrsquos most scenic and historic races ndash the Stirling Scottish Marathon.: Bid to save Glasgow bowling club as housing plans submittedThousands of runners at every fitness level will take to the picturesque roads in and around Stirling for the two-day running festival in October, including GB basketball Olympian and marathon ambassador Kieron Achara, who will become Scotlandrsquos tallest marathon runner at ft in when he takes on the course.ldquoI will get to run such a scenic and historic route in and around my hometown, he said. ldquoThat in itself will make this a great experience.ldquoIt can be dficult for athletes leaving their sport to keep busy and setting new goals can definitely help with that.The event caters for shorter distances too, with participants able to take on k and k courses, alongside a family mile and a half marathon at Kingrsquos Park.The spectacular route takes in some of Scotlandrsquos most iconic sights and stunning countryside ndash from the unmistakable Stirling Castle and Wallace Monument, to the picturesque towns and villages of Doune, Dunblane and Bridge of Allan.Team GB athlete Callum Hawkins, the Scottish record holder for the marathon, echoed calls for first-time runners to get involved in what he describes as one of Scotlandrsquos great athletic events.ldquoWhether you are a first-time marathoner, running for charity, or just looking for a personal best, the Stirling Scottish Marathon fits the bill, he said.ldquoThe course is well known as one of the most picturesque and scenic marathon courses in the world with tremendous support in every village and town that the runners pass through. Scotland needs great events like this.It is the first year the race has been taken over by new organisers Classic Run Events, who changed the timing of this yearrsquos event from springtime to autumn.They say the revised date will give local and national runners ldquomore flexibility to prepare for the course and hope it will invite more applicants.: Margaret Fleming case made for gripping TV viewingPrevious marathons have attracted more than , runners, including Olympic athlete Derek Hawkins, brother of Callum, and Outlander star Heughan.But it is not just well-known faces gearing up to take part. Glasgow woman Esme Greenan said participating in this yearrsquos race will help push her closer to her goal of completing  marathons by the time she turns .The now- year-old has so far completed seven of her ultimate target, including one in Reykjavik, and has plans to take on the Stirling Scottish Marathon straight after the Glencoe Marathon in September.ldquoI know that it is a huge challenge to hit my target, but I am in love with the distance and motivated to complete as many as I can, she said.Paul Drever, , has only been running for a couple of years but will take on the full marathon distance for the first time in his le on October .Mr Drever has a rare Schizoaffective Disorder, a combination of both Schizophrenia and Bipolar Disorder, and spent much of his youth receiving treatment in and out of hospital.However he is now off medication, in work and conducting part-time study, and credits running as one of the biggest positive influences in his le.The winner of the menrsquos and womenrsquos elite competition will walk away with a pound, cash prize, with other funded prizes available for the top three runners in each age group. Other races over the two-day festivalinclude the half marathon, k, k, family mile, junior run and corporate relay.Entry to the Stirling Scottish Marathon starts at pound.The Herald has partnered with organisers to offer readers a special  per cent discount on entry to any of the events at the two-day festival.To claim the discount, all you need to do is sign up to a three-month trial of heraldscotland for just pound.You will receive unlimited access to an advert light version of our website, a digital page-turning replica sent to your device every morning, access to daily newsletters and a news app for your Apple or Android Smartphone and more. at heraldscotland subscribe smTCs apply.

title: funding boost for inverurie men s shed
story: Inverurie  District Men#s Shed has become the latest beneficiary of the Barratt Homes North Scotland Community Fund giveaway.The group will be using its £, windfall from the housebuilder to help fund the regeneration of a leased field, allowing the group to build a new polytunnel for growing fruits and vegetables.Inverurie  District Men’s Shed is one of more than  Men’s Sheds in Scotland and all have been created with the aim of improving members’ wellbeing, social interaction and co-operation.More than  members are part of Inverurie  District Men’s Shed – located at Harlaw Industrial Estate – and many work on their own skills-based projects, including building wooden planters, repairing household items, making benches or crafting seasonal themed items.The new field was recently offered to the group by a generous local landowner and is expected to provide the Men’s Shed with enough space to create allotments to grow their own produce and build and maintain gardening skills.Archie Peebles from Inverurie District Men’s Shed, said: “Our group is only able to exist thanks to the generosity of local iniduals and businesses like Barratt Homes. Local support means everything to us and we’re incredibly thankful for this £, gt.”David Palmer, Managing Director for Barratt North Scotland, said: “Improving and maintaining positive wellbeing during our daily lives is crucial. Men’s Shed’s across the country do a fantastic job of getting people involved, reducing loneliness and helping create better, more circular communities.“We look forward to helping them where we can in the future.”data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The children at Rothienorman School enjoyed the visit from the SSEN Transmission team"  SSEN talk to bright spark pupils viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: mackie s launches world s first haggis neeps and tatties crisps
story: Haggis, neeps and tatties will be available in potato crisp form this month thanks to Mackies Crisps.Due to hit the shelves from early January, Mackie’s Crisps has taken inspiration from the Bard himself, Robert Burns, and is bringing consumers a snack-based taste of Scotland’s favourite traditional dish in the run-up to Burns Night.A limited run of , g bags will be available with a comforting, light peppery flavour and Taylor-clan tartan packaging.Using entirely natural flavourings and high oleic sunflower oil, the crisps are suitable for both vegans and vegetarians.James Taylor, from the Perthshire-based family business, is delighted with the flavour and hopes it resonates with the Scottish public.He said: “While we do push the boat out with exotic flavours, we do also like to look closer to home at some of the fantastic dishes from our heritage. Quite simply, there are none more iconic than our own national dish.“We’re fiercely proud of our Scottish roots and so narrowed down to a number of options for a limited run. When it came to the taste tests, haggis, neeps and tatties emerged as the runaway favourite.”James is the fourth generation to work at the Taylor farm – and is Commercial Director at Mackie’s at Taypack, which produces Mackie’s Crisps. He helps to run the family-owned business with his father, Managing Director George Taylor.The crisps brand and Mackie’s at Taypack as a business were launched in  as the result of a joint-venture between potato farmers the Taylor family and Aberdeenshire’s Mackie’s of Scotland, which is renowned for its ice cream and chocolate.Its thick-cut and gently cooked potato crisps use the best ieties of crisping potatoes, grown on the farm, reflective of its “plough to pack” ethos.Subsequently, Mackie’s Crisps has become famous for its haggis and cracked black pepper iety, as well as launching the world’s first pigs in blankets flavour.Research on its new flavour started in earnest in  during a new product development push, after establishing Burns Night as an opening to deliver a new patriotic flavour combination.Meticulous sampling sessions helped it to master the flavour of haggis, neeps and tatties, building on its popular haggis-based flavours.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Members of Inverurie  District Mens Shed accept the donation from Barratt Homes"  Funding boost for Inverurie Men’s Shed viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"The Mackie’s Crisps team were further convinced of launching the flavour when a student, Aileen McColm, joined the Perthshire business in  to shadow quality control manager Jamie McKell. She undertook a survey, with  respondents showing the flavour to be the favoured option for the target market. James added: “It’s been many years in the making, so we’ll be keeping in contact with our end customers and trade clients throughout to see what the appetite is like for our new flavour.“Who knows, we may even be able to expand the run to make it a permanent addition to our range. We’d also love to be able to sell bags abroad, helping the wider world to experience the taste of haggis, neeps and tatties.”

title: ssen talk to bright spark pupils
story: SSEN Transmission staff visited Rothienorman School last month to talk to the children about how energy works and how they can stay road safe during construction.The staff are currently working on the construction of the Rothienorman substation, which forms part of SSEN Transmission’s reinforcement and improvement of the transmission network in the North East and East Coast of Scotland.The school visit marked a busy couple of weeks for the team, following visits to the substation site by members of the local community, Fisherford Community Council and Rothienorman Community Association.During their visit they talked to the pupils about the key role Rothienorman substation will play in facilitating the connection of renewable energy to the National Grid on the North East Coast.They also showed them how the substation will help control the flow of energy across the north east, directing renewable energy generated around Peterhead, and assist with the delivery of energy to where it’s needed, while highlighting the key role SSEN Transmission plays in supporting the transition to Net Zero.Finally they used their visit to talk about staying safe around increased local and construction traffic and gave each pupil a high visibility vest and snap band to wear when travelling to and from school on dark mornings and winter nights, helping the children to “think bright” about road safety and improve their visibility to drivers on the road.Following the visit Gary Donlin, SSEN Transmission’s Community Liaison Manager, commented: “We really enjoyed our visit to Rothienorman School.“It was great to see the children so interested in finding out how energy works and the role SSEN Transmission plays in facilitating renewable generation and the transition to Net Zero.”Mr Donlin added: “We have been working closely with community since the early development of the project and this has continued into construction, it is important to us to ensure we work together to actively mitigate any impacts of the works.“We were pleased we were able to talk about keeping road safe around construction traffic and give the children high-vis to help themselves to be seen by drivers during the dark mornings and nights.”Work on the substation began in April this year and is expected to be completed in summer .data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch story: Trade reached a top of # at Aberdeen and Northern Marts# th anniversary show and sale of store cattle on Friday, January .Sale leader on the day was a -month-old British Blue cross heer from brothers William and David Moir of Moir Livestock, Newmill of Rathen, Fraserburgh, who sold  heers to average p per kg.Weighing kg, their sale topper was an unshown heer bred by A MacDonald, The Ess, Carrbridge, which sold to Gordon Cameron, Newton Cottage, Acharacle, Argyll.Two other Limousin cross heers from Moir Livestock made £, apiece when sold to Gary Bell, Haaside, Lockerbie, while another sold for £, to A and E Neachell and Son, Shrubbery Farm, Aldridge, Staffordshire.The champion in the pre-sale show, sponsored by Thomson of Sauchen, was awarded to a -month-old Limousin cross heer from Steven Smith, The Byre, Sunnyhill Croft, Turrf.Tapped out by judges Gavin and Stuart Ross, Wardhead, Strichen, was a kg heer bred by George Jack, Woodend, Killearnan, Muir of Ord, which later sold for £, to J Gordon and Co, Waterside of Forbes, Alford.The reserve honours went to a -month-old Charolais cross heer weighing kg from Moir Livestock.This was a heer bred by A Smith, The Leys, Tarland, Aboyne, which made £, when purchased by Mark Baxter, The Bungalow, Troup Home Farm, Gamrie, Banff.AC Fotheringham, Ballinloan, Dunkeld, Perth, stood champion in the home-bred section with a -month-old Limousin cross heer. title: calls for urgent review of ambulance cover in orkney
story: newsCalls for urgent review of ambulance cover in OrkneyJanuary ,  at : am vw, px"  Orkney MSP Liam McArthurOrkney’s MSP, Liam McArthur, is calling for an urgent review into ambulance cover in Orkney.Last month, Mr McArthur raised with ministers concerns that emergency calls risked being left waiting while Orkney’s only land ambulance was responding to another call.He also askedOrkney had been left without land ambulance cover for a period of time over the past year.In response, the minister for public health, Joe Fitzpatrick, has written to Mr McArthur confirming that there were  occasions between December , , and December ,  when emergency calls in Orkney were left waiting due to the ambulance responding to another call.There was also an occasion when Orkney was left without any ambulance cover on the mainland and linked south isles for two hours.Commenting on the minister’s response, Mr McArthur said: “These figures reveal the extent to which land ambulance capacity in Orkney is failing to meet the needs of patients. People in Orkney will be shocked to hear how often those making emergency calls are being forced to wait due to a lack of land ambulance cover. In many instances, these will be cases where the response time can be critical.“This is absolutely no criticism of Orkney’s ambulance crews, who do outstanding work in operating a service that is clearly over-stretched. Indeed, the admission from the Minister about the scale of the problem shows that local crews are being let down by a lack of resources and support. This can only be making an already dficult job even more challenging.“I am due to meet senior representatives of the Scottish Ambulance Service early next month. I will make clear the need for an urgent review into the resources available locally and calling for additional capacity to meet the needs of the Orkney community. This is the very least that the public and our ambulance staff deserve.#copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: council seek your views on quanterness wind farm
story: Feedback is being invited into a major development which would see a six-turbine wind farm be constructed on the outskirts of Kirkwall.Orkney Islands Council, as part of their community wind farm project, intend to submit a planning application for six turbines at Quanterness, St Ola, in early .The development is set to consist of six turbines with a maximum blade-tip height of .-metres and associated infrastructure such as hardstandings, access tracks, a met mast and a substation compound.Public exhibitions unveiling the project, which would also see turbines placed in Faray and Hoy, were held in November.In December, councillors voted that applications pertaining to the project be taken over by the Scottish Government rather than be solely decided at local level here in Orkney.Now, with the proposals classed as a “major development” there is a requirement for the council to carry out a pre-application consultation.This consultation is used to inform communities about major and national development proposals and to have an opportunity to contribute views before a formal planning application is submitted.The deadline for submitting comments and views to the project team has been extended to pm on Friday, January , and feedback forms can be found on the council website here.Alternatively, feedback can be provided by phone on .copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: freight ship to be back on pentland firth route
story: NorthLink Ferries has confirmed that the freight ship Helliar is to operate on the Pentland Firth route while the Hamnavoe is away in drydock from next week.The Hamnavoe is due to be in drydock from this coming Monday, January , until Sunday January .The company says that there will be additional north and southbound calls into Kirkwall by the Hrossey and Hjaltland during this time.A NorthLink spokesperson added: #The Hamnavoe, which operates between Scrabster and Stromness will have “Changing Places” installed during the upcoming dry dock period. These fully accessible facilities have an adult-sized, height adjustable changing bench, a hoist and a centrally placed toilet. NorthLink have worked closely with the Scottish charity PAMIS to ensure these are to specication and are delighted to be the first ferry operator to have these toilets on all passenger vessels.#Giving further details of the work due to be undertaken, they added: #The availability of an external power supply, a shore supply, will be utilised to complete the final vessel commissioning of the onboard modications to the vessel’s electrical switchboard to accept shore power.#Various mechanical works will be undertaken, including major services on the port main engine, starboard main engine and the port gearbox. All works are planned maintenance tasks complying with the manufacturer’s recommended service schedules and overseen by the manufacturer’s approved service engineers.#Drydock maintenance will also be completed on propellers, shaft lines and stabilisers along with statutory out of water surveys and inspections by the Classication Society and Flag Administration.#The company, who have in the past been criticised for putting the freight ship on the route, further stated that the scheduled drydock period has been designed to minimise disruption to customers, and takes place during the quietest time of year for both passenger and freight shipments.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. However, the road will remain closed for a further three weeks to ensure the construction materials have set.During this time residents and businesses should continue to put out their waste bins as normal at am on waste collection days. story: The weather gods shined on Stromness as the town celebrated the final day of  with the now annual Yule Log contests.A huge crowd flocked to the town to witness the Northenders win their first Yule Log battle since its revival in , winning the junior spectacle.Beginning outside the Pier Arts Centre, the Soothenders put up stf resistance yet there was simply no stopping a determined and vocal north side.Both the junior and senior battles were over in a matter of minutes, however, that failed to dampen the enthusiasm and spirit around the town.The senior contest begun outside the Commercial Hotel and for the opening minutes, it appeared asthe much smaller team of the north would turn the contest their way, inching the -kilogram log back towards their goal of the Pierhead.The town#s chinese takeaway shop would be as far as they got however.The Soothenders reorganised themselves and turned the tide. title: carlos-ghosn-detention-japan-travesty-human-rights
story: Nissan’s former chairman Carlos Ghosn speaks at a press conference in Beirut, LebanonNissanrsquos fugitive ex-chairman Carlos Ghosn has described his arrest in Japan, from which he escaped last month, as a plot against him and his detention conditions as a ldquotravesty against human rights.In his first appearance since his daring and improbable escape from Japan, Ghosn told a news conference in Beirut that the decision to flee ldquowas the most dficult of my le.He was due to stand trial for alleged financial misconduct at the carmaker and on Wednesday again dismissed all allegations against him as untrue.With big gestures and a five-part slide presentation projected behind him, Ghosn brought his case to the global media and said his view on fleeing Japan was: ldquoYou are going to die in Japan or you are going to get out. -- --In response, Japanrsquos justice minister Masako Mori said Ghosnrsquos comments were unfounded and she wanted to prevent him spreading an ldquoerroneous understanding abroad.ldquoNone of his claims can justy the fact he fled Japan illegally, she said.Chief government spokesman Yoshihide Suga added that whether Ghosn would be extradited was Lebanonrsquos decision but that Japan would cooperate closely with international organisations ldquoso that Japanrsquos criminal justice system can be operated appropriately.Ghosn said he would not address the details of his escape, which has perplexed and embarrassed Japanese authorities.Media reports have said he left his Tokyo residence alone, skipping bail despite supposedly rigorous surveillance. He met two men at a hotel and then took a bullet train to Osaka before boarding a private jet hidden inside a case for musical equipment. He flew to Istanbul and was then transferred on to another plane bound for Beirut, where he arrived on December .Ghosn portrayed his arrest as a plot linked to a decline in the financial performance of Nissan. He had been in favour of merging Nissan with industry ally Renault, of which he was also chairman. --Grab of a photo made available by IHA of packing crates, one of which IHA claims Carlos Ghosn used to hide to escape from Japan--ldquoUnfortunately there was no trust. And some of our Japanese friends thought that the only way to get rid of Renault in Nissan is to get rid of me, he said.ldquoI should never have been arrested in the first place, he said.ldquoIrsquom not above the law and I welcome the opportunity for the truth to come out and have my name cleared, he told a packed room of journalists.Ghosn said he would be ready to stand trial ldquoanywhere where I think I can have a fair trial. He declined to say what country that might be.Lebanon last week received an Interpol-issued wanted notice ndash a non-binding request to law enforcement agencies worldwide that they locate and provisionally arrest a fugitive.Lebanon and Japan do not have an extradition treaty, and the Interpol notice does not require Lebanon to arrest him. Lebanese authorities have said Ghosn entered the country on a legal passport, casting doubt on the possibility they would hand him over to Japan. -- vw,vw,px, px"Carlos Ghosn faces the media--At the request of the Japanese government, Interpol published the notice on its website on Wednesday as Ghosn was giving his news conference. The notice was previously only sent to Interpolrsquos member governments but not shared with the public.Ghosn, who is Lebanese and also holds French and Brazilian passports, was expected to go on trial in Tokyo in April. In earlier statements, he has said he fled to avoid ldquopolitical persecution by a ldquorigged Japanese justice system. He also said that he alone organised his departure from Japan and that his we Carole played no role.On Tuesday, Tokyo prosecutors obtained an arrest warrant for Mrs Ghosn on suspicion of perjury. That charge is not related to his escape. Lebanonrsquos justice minister said Lebanon has not received any request related to that warrant. -- vw,vw,px, px"Journalists outside the house of Carlos Ghosn in Beirut--Japanese justice officials acknowledge that it is unclear whether the Ghosns can be brought back to Japan to face charges.Ghosnrsquos former employer, Nissan Motor Co, said it was still pursuing legal action against him despite his escape, adding that Ghosn engaged in serious misconduct while leading the Nissan-Renault-Mitsubishi alliance. Ghosn denies all the charges.In France, meanwhile, prosecutors are investigating a ,-eurogt from the chateau of Versailles to Ghosn, linked to a lavish party there. Renault alerted French authorities after a company investigation found that Ghosn personally benefited from ldquoan exchange worth , euros in the framework of a philanthropic accord signed with the Chateau of Versailles.Renault said in June that an internal audit with partner Nissan found  million eurosin questionable expenses at their Dutch-based holding linked to Ghosn. The two carmakers recommended legal action in the Netherlands, where the alliance is based, and ordering Ghosn himself to reimburse the company for some of the expenses.Earlier in the day, Tokyo prosecutors raided a Japanese lawyerrsquos office where Ghosn had visited regularly before he fled.-- vw,vw,px, px"Carlos Ghosn and his we Carole--Japanese media reports said prosecutors were likely to have seized a computer to track down how Ghosn escaped and who might have helped him.An hour before the scheduled press conference, a Lebanese prosecutor said Ghosn will be summoned ldquoin the coming hours over a visit to Israel more than  years ago, according to the state-run National News Agency.Two Lebanese lawyers had submitted a report to the Public Prosecutorrsquos Office against Ghosn last week, saying he violated Lebanese law by visiting Israel. The two neighbouring countries are technically in a state of war. Prosecutor Ghassan Khoury met with the two lawyers who filed the case on Wednesday and asked them to bring additional evidence, adding he would summon Ghosn in the coming hours.Ghosn visited Israel in  and met officials including the prime minister and the president. At the time, he announced the launch of electric cars in Israel.copy -. This site is part of Newsquests audited local newspaper network. A Gannett Company. title: uk-youngsters-miles-behind-european-peers-foreign-language-learning
story: EU flag and Union JackLearning a foreign language should be compulsory for GCSE students, according to a report that warns the UK is falling behind its European neighbours in language ability.Scrapping the subject at GCSE level ndash a decision made by Tony Blairrsquos Labour government ndash led to a severe drop-off in the numbers taking languages such as French and German, a new study by the Higher Education Policy Institutesays.Fewer than half of pupils in England, Wales and Northern Ireland now take a GCSE foreign language, it argues, compared to three in four in . The study also notes that the UKrsquos young people are ldquomiles behind their European peers in foreign languages, with just a third able to speak more than just their mother tongue.And it warns that post-Brexit, language skills cannot be ignored, and the UK cannot rely on the assumption that the rest of the world speaks English.The study says there has been a huge drop in demand for language learning in recent years.ldquoIn England, Wales and Northern Ireland, the scrapping of the compulsory foreign language GCSE in  has had a detrimental effect on national uptake levels, the paper says.ldquoThis measure failed to anticipate the vast drop in uptake. ldquoGiven fewer than half of pupils now take a GCSE foreign language, compared to % in , we are far behind the rest of Europe, and changes in governmental attitudes and policy are pressing. The author calculates that at GCSE, entries for French have dropped by % since , while German entries have fallen %.There has been a rise in the numbers taking Spanish over this period, overtaking German in , and last year there was an overall rise in the numbers taking modern foreign languages.The report also says that entries for French and German A-level have been falling since the mid-s, and there has been a fall in recent years in the numbers applying to study certain languages at university.The falls are having an impact on the languages ldquopipeline, the report suggests, affecting the numbers of language graduates and trained teachers. This, along with reductions in EU school staff, will threaten languages in schools, it says.The study concludes: ldquoThe assumption that lsquothe rest of the world speaks Englishrsquo hinders new international collaborations and overlooks cultural and cognitive enhancement developed by learning.ldquoPolitical developments mean change is more pressing. If the UK is to thrive outside the EU, language skills cannot be ignored ndash the UK must address educational declines and capitalise on lsquountapped reservoirs of linguistic capacityrsquo.ldquoIt is crucial that ancient and modern languages receive support in schools and higher education. The report puts forward a series of recommendations, including calling for foreign language study to be compulsory at GCSE level, with youngsters encouraged, but not obliged to take an accredited GCSE or alternative qualication.Report author Megan Bowler, a third-year Classics undergraduate at the University of Oxford, said: ldquoIt was a big mistake to scrap compulsory foreign languages at GCSE.ldquoRather than continuing to present languages as not suitable for everyone, we need to include a broader range of pupils learning through a iety of qualications geared to dferent needs.Nick Hillman, HEPI director said: ldquoThe decision to limit language learning in schools by making GCSE languages voluntary is probably the single most damaging education policy implemented in England so far this century.ldquoThe UK is bottom of the pile for the number of young people familiar with another language, and miles behind every EU country.A Department for Education spokesman said: ldquoWe are committed to ensuring more pupils are studying languages, which is why it is compulsory for all children between years three and nine.ldquoThe introduction of the EBacc halted the decline in languages and since  the proportion of pupils studying a language at GCSE has risen from % to % in . ldquoWe are also taking a range of steps to make sure that the uptake of languages continues to increase, such as creating a new network of schools and funding programmes like our Mandarin Excellence Programme.copy -. title: baftas 2020 jessie buckley in running for role as glaswegian country singer in wild rose
story: Buckley, whose character Rose-Lynn Harlan dreams of finding fame in Nashville after being released from jail, will be up against Reneacutee Zellweger, her co-star in Judy, for the leading actress honour.Other contenders include Scarlett Johansson for Marriage Story, Saoirse Ronan for Little Women and Charlize Theron for Bombshell.Written by Glaswegian screenwriter Nicole Taylor, Wild Rose - which also featured Julie Walters as Buckleyrsquos on-screen mother - was hailed by critics as Scotlandrsquos answer to A Star Is Born.Oscar-winning American songwriter Mary Steenburgen is on the shortlist for an Academy Award for the closing anthem she wrote for the finale ofWild Rose, Glasgow . which was set at the citys Celtic Connections festival.The film, which was shot on location around the city, including venues like the Grand Ole Opry and the Old Fruitmarket, won three honours at the BAFTA Scotland Awards in Glasgow in November, including best film actress for Buckley.Another Glasgow-set film, love story Only You, the feature debut of writer-director Harry Wootlf, has won her a nomination in the outstanding debut category.window.twttr Sorry We Missed You, award-winning Scottish screenwriter Paul Lavertyrsquos latest movie with his long-time collaborator, director Ken Loach, is nominated for best British film. Leith-based actor Jack Lowden, whose recent films include Dunkirk, Morrissey biopic England Is Mine, and Highland-set Netflix thriller Calibre and historical drama Mary Queen of Scots, is in the running for BAFTAs ldquorising star award.Johansson is also nominated in the best supporting actress category for her performance in Jojo Rabbit. Other nominees include Laura Dern for Marriage Story, Florence Pugh for Little Women, and Margot Robbie, who is nominated twice, for Bombshell and Once Upon a Time in Hollywood.Best supporting actor contenders include Al Pacino and Joe Pesci, who are both nominated for The Irishman, Tom Hanks for A Beautul Day in the Neighborhood, Anthony Hopkins for The Two Popes and Brad Pitt for Once Upon a Time in Hollywood.Written by Glaswegian screenwriter Nicole Taylor, Wild Rose was hailed by critics as Scotlands answer to A Star Is Born.The film, which was shot on location around the city, including venues like the Grand Ole Opry and the Old Fruitmarket, won three honours at the BAFTA Scotland Awards in Glasgow in November, including best film actress for Buckley.Buckley, who starred opposite Julie Walters, who played her on-screen mother in Wild Rose, ed to Glasgow for its Scottish premiere in February at the citys film festival.Read more: Interview: Irish actress Jessie Buckley on embracing lsquoWeegie mentalityrsquo to convince as Glasgow country singer in Wild RoseShe told at the time how she "worked my *** off" to try to give a convincing performance as a cleaner struggling to make her way as a singer while bringing up two young children after being released from behind bars.The -year-old made several incognito visits to the Grand Ole Opry club - which features in several key scenes - and went drinking with the cast and crew to pubs like The Laurieston Bar and The Ben Nevis to try to get into ldquothe Weegie mentality.Buckley, who stars opposite Julie Walters in the new film. said she even tied to dupe shopkeepers around the city by buying cigarettes in her adopted accent.She said: "The story in the film is really a story of identity, where you are from and the four corners that you are told you are only allowed to dream in. Being a Glasgow girl is so much part of Rose-Lynnrsquos make-up.ldquoHonest to God, I love Glasgow so much now. It stole my heart. The people are so open and there is a real humanity behind Glaswegians.ldquoI was so nervous that I wouldnrsquot be authentic, but I worked my **** off so that I could get a close to the core as I possibly could.ldquoI based myself in Glasgow for a month before we started shooting. I was working with a dialect coach and the two of us would go out and Irsquod speak in a Glasgow accent all day.ldquoI basically just took to the streets and also went into dferent newsagents around Glasgow and tried to ask for a packet of fags.ldquoI took a lot of trips to The Ben Nevis, The Laurieston and all these other joints. Theyrsquore pure rust and real le.ldquoWhen you fall in love with the city and you fall in love with the people and fall in love with the character who symbolises all that in some way it is kind of scary letting it out.ldquoI want to do Glasgow proud. It means a lot to me.ldquoWe did a cast and crew screening in Glasgow. I donrsquot think I took a breath.ldquoWhen the film finished a woman turned around and gave me a hug. I literally just burst out crying.Only You charts the evolution of a relationship between an office worker and a student who meet in Glasgow on Hogmanay.Read more: Writer-director Harry Wootlf on her new Glasgow-set movie, Only YouDiscussing the movie ahead of its Scottish premiere at the Glasgow Film Festival last year, Wootlf said: "I wanted to write a relationship story ndash a love story ndash that felt really intimate and real."I wanted to do something that was about the endurance of love through the ups and downs of staying together after the initial falling-in-love phase is over."Isabel Davis, executive director at Screen Scotland said: ldquoScottish talent is represented across the BAFTA nominations, notably the writer Paul Laverty for outstanding British film for Sorry We Missed You and Jack Lowden in the rising star category."Nicole Taylorrsquos love letter to her hometown of Glasgow, Wild Rose has rightly been recognised through Jessie Buckleyrsquos tour de force performance.
